questions.text: Which of the following accurately describes Sampson's theory for endometriosis?
questions.solution:
Sampson's theory describes the implantation of endometrial tissue due to retrograde menstruation.

The various theories for the etiology of endometriosis include:

Theory Mechanism
Sampson's implantation theory Reflux of menstrual endometrium and subsequent implantation in the surrounding structures
Theory of coelomic metaplasia by Meyer and Ivanoff

Metaplastic changes in embryonic mesothelium which respond to hormone stimulation
Metastatic theory by Halban Embolization of menstrual fragments through vascular and lymphatic channels
Theory of histogenesis by induction Induction of undifferentiated peritoneal cells to endometrial tissue by an endogenous factor

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about endometriosis?

choices.text: In utero exposure to DES increases risk
Most common site is the cervix

questions.solution:
The most common site of occurrence of endometriosis is the ovary. Endometriosis of the ovary is known as endometrioma.

By definition, endometriosis is the occurrence of benign endometrial tissue (glands and stroma) outside the cavity of the uterus. Endometriosis can occur anywhere in the body (except spleen) including the abdominal wall, lung, pleura, brain, etc.

It is a proliferative, hormone-dependent disease of the childbearing period. Women between the age groups of 30-40 years are most commonly affected. Risk factors for endometriosis are as follows:

  • Family history (7-10x risk with a 1st-degree relative)
  • Nulliparity
  • In utero exposure to Diethylstilbestrol (DES)
  • Estrogen dependent conditions/Estrogen therapy
  • Immunological factor - Impaired T cell and NK cell activity and altered immunology in a woman may increase the susceptibility to proliferation and growth.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common symptom associated with endometriosis?
questions.solution:
The most common symptom of endometriosis is dysmenorrhea.

Pain begins before the onset of menstruation and builds up continu­ously until the flow starts. Thereafter, the pain gradually de­clines. This pattern of pain is called triple dysmenorrhea.

questions.text: In a patient diagnosed with endometriosis, which of the following symptoms would you not expect?
questions.solution:
Patients diagnosed with endometriosis are not likely to present with vaginal discharge.

Clinical features of endometriosis include:

  • About 30% of the patients are asymptomatic.
  • The classic symptom complex includes:
    • Dysmenorrhoea
    • Dyspareunia
    • Menorrhagia
    • Infertility (30-40%)
  • Dysmenorrhoea - most common symptom
  • Dyspareunia - occurs when the pouch of Douglas and rectovaginal septum are involved.
  • Deep-seated pelvic pain
  • Premenstrual and postmenstrual spotting

questions.text: A 26-year-old lady presented with complaints of severe pain on menstruation and heavy flow. She is subsequently diagnosed with endometriosis. The pain in this condition mainly correlates with_____
questions.solution:
Pain in endometriosis mainly correlates with the depth of penetration.

Lesions penetrating more than 5mm are responsible for pain, dysmenorrhea and dyspareunia. The dysmenorrhea associated with endometriosis precedes menses by 24 to 48 hours and is less responsive to NSAIDs and combined OCPs.

questions.text:
Arrange the following sites of endometriosis in the order of frequency of occurrence.
  1. Pouch of Douglas
  2. Uterosacral ligament
  3. Broad ligament
  4. Ovary
  5. Fallopian tube
questions.solution:
The sites of endometriosis arranged in the order of frequency of occurrence are: Ovary > Pouch of Douglas > Broad ligament > Uterosacral ligament > Fallopian tube.

Endometriotic lesions have been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Related Pearl: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

  • Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.
  • Rectovaginal endometriosis.
  • Ovarian endometriosis.
  • Chocolate cyst of the ovary.
  • Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.
  • Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

  • Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.
  • Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.
  • Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).
    • Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.
    • Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented with dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, and infertility. On examination, you note tender nodularity of the uterosacral ligaments. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the tender nodularity of the uterosacral ligament points towards a diagnosis of endometriosis.

The nodularity of the uterosacral ligament in endometriosis gives rise to the cobblestone appearance seen on laparoscopy. This is referred to as 'sine qua non of endometriosis'.

questions.text: A young woman presented to your clinic with complaints of painful menstruation and postmenstrual spotting. On examination, you note tender nodules in the posterior fornix and a fixed retroverted uterus. Which of the following is the gold standard investigation to confirm the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of dysmenorrhea with tender nodules in the posterior fornix and a retroverted uterus is suggestive of endometriosis. The gold standard investigation for the diagnosis of this condition is a visual inspection by laparoscopy, preferably with histological confirmation. It is also the investigation of choice for the condition.

Role of laparoscopy in endometriosis:

  • Detect and diagnose pelvic endometriosis
  • Locate the site of endometriosis and staging
  • To take biopsy
  • To surgically treat endometriosis by ablation

Other investigations for endometriosis include:

  • Estimation of CA-125 levels - raised in endometriosis.
  • Estimation of MCP-1 (Monocyte chemotactic protein) levels - raised in the peritoneal fluid of women with endometriosis.

questions.text: A diagnostic laparoscopy was performed on a 27-year-old woman with severe dysmenorrhoea and dyspareunia.  The following finding was seen on the pelvic peritoneum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the image showing characteristic powder burn spots seen over the pelvic peritoneum on laparoscopy point toward a diagnosis of pelvic endometriosis.

On laparoscopy, the typical endometriotic lesions appear like small black, dark brown or bluish dots. These are called powder burns or gunshot appearance of the serosal surfaces of the peritoneum. They are nodules or small cysts containing old haemorrhages surrounded by a variable degree of fibrosis.

Subtle appearances of endometriosis seen on laparoscopy are:

  • Red flame-shaped areas
  • Red polypoid areas
  • Yellow-brown patches
  • White peritoneal plaques or scarring
  • Peritoneal defects - known as Allen Masters Syndrome
  • Subovarian adhesions.

The lesions mentioned above are thought to be more active than the powder burn areas.

Endometriotic lesions in the peritoneal cavity contain yellowish-brown fluid. This fluid contains prostaglandins that are responsible for the pain associated with this condition. Endometriosis of the ovary leads to formation of the chocolate cyst which is a true cyst with columnar epithelium lining.

The image below shows the laparoscopic appearance of endometriotic lesions in the pouch of Douglas and on the right, the sacrouterine ligament. Dyspareunia occurs when the pouch of Douglas and rectovaginal septum are involved.

questions.text: In endometriotic lesion, histology represents its:
questions.solution:
In endometriotic lesions, histology represents its high estrogen activity.

Endometriosis is defined by the presence of “ectopic” endometrial tissue at a site outside of the uterus.  Endometriosis is a proliferative hormone-dependent disease of the childbearing period. It is extremely rare before menarche and disappears after menopause.

The endometriotic implants show certain differences when compared to normal endometrium. There is increased production of estrogen by endometriotic stromal cells due to high levels of the enzyme aromatase. This is absent in normal endometrial stroma.

questions.text: Which of the following operative procedures are least likely to be followed by scar endometriosis?
questions.solution:
Among the given operative procedures, hysterectomy is least likely to be followed by scar endometriosis.

Operations most likely to be followed by scar endometriosis are:

  • Hysterotomy
  • Classical Cesarean section
  • Myomectomy
  • Ventrofixation (fixing uterus to the abdominal wall)
  • Episiotomy

questions.text: A 39-year-old nulliparous woman presented with dysmenorrhea and a progressively growing, painless abdominal mass. USG scan revealed a cystic lesion of the left ovary which was excised. The below image shows the excised specimen. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?

choices.text: It is seen in endometriosis of ovary
It is lined by columnar epithelium
It is usually a bilateral condition
It is a malignant cystic lesion

questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the image is suggestive of a chocolate cyst of the ovary which is a benign cystic lesion.

Chocolate cysts of the ovary are a manifestation of endometriosis. Both the ovaries are usually affected. On histology, the cyst is lined by columnar epithelium. Pseudoxanthoma cells are present which are large macrophages or scavenger cells that appear brown in colour due to ingested blood pigments such as ­haemosiderin. They are polyhe­dral in shape and resemble lutein cells.

questions.text: A patient is being evaluated for chronic abdominal pain. Her lab reports revealed elevated CA-125 levels. Which of the following conditions is the least likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
CA-125 levels are not expected to be elevated in malignant pancreatic tumours.

CA-125 is a glycoprotein and cell surface antigen. Its levels are raised in the following conditions:

  • Abdominal or pelvic tuberculosis
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease
  • Endometriosis
  • Malignant epithelial ovarian tumour­
  • Chronic liver disease
  • 2% of normal women, especially during menstruation.

Endometrioma refers to ovarian endometriosis. CA-125 levels are raised to more than 35 U/mL in 80% of cases of endometriosis. The level is directly proportional to the extent of the disease.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with dyspareunia is diagnosed to have endometriosis. Which of the following drugs is not useful for her treatment?
questions.solution:
Estrogen is not used in the treatment of endometriosis as the condition is estrogen-dependent.

For minimal disease, the drug of choice is NSAIDs. Oral contraceptive pills are given if associated menstrual complaints are present. OCPs inhibit gonadotropin release and decrease the menstrual flow.

For moderate to severe disease, oral progestogens are the first drugs to be started. They are known to antagonize estrogenic effects on the endometrium causing endometrial atrophy. The drug of choice is GnRH agonists.

Note: The best time to conceive in a patient with endometriosis is immediately after surgery.

questions.text: A patient with endometriosis requires treatment with GnRH analogues. She is scared of injections so you plan to prescribe a nasal preparation for her.  Which of the following GnRH agonists could you prescribe?
questions.solution:
The GnRH agonist available as a nasal preparation for the treatment of endometriosis is nafarelin.

GnRH analogues are used in the management of endometriosis and are given by continuous administration. This suppresses the secretion of pituitary gonadotropins and leads to atrophy of the endometrial tissue in 90% of cases.

Leuprolide and triptorelin are GnRH agonists which are given IM. Goserelin is available as a depot preparation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding adenomyosis?
questions.solution:
Patients with adenomyosis commonly present with symptoms of menorrhagia and dysmenorrhea.

Adenomyosis (endometriosis interna) is the ingrowth of stromal and glandular components of the endometrium directly into the myometrium. It usually occurs following vigorous curettage, repeated childbirth or in conditions with an excess of estrogen. Adenomyosis is more common in multiparous women aged 40 years and above. They commonly present with menorrhagia and dysmenorrhea. Other symptoms include pelvic discomfort, backache and dyspareunia.

On per-vaginal examination, there is a gross symmetrical enlargement of the uterus corresponding to 12-14 weeks size. The uterus is soft and tender on bimanual examination. This is known as Halban's sign. 

Diagnosis is mainly based on clinical assessment. A diagnostic hysteroscopy combined with curettage is the initial step in the management because of menorrhagia. Total hysterectomy is the treatment of choice. Localised excision and levonorgestrel containing IUCD can be tried in younger patients.

The image below is an illustration of adenomyosis.

The image below shows adenomyosis as seen during laparoscopy. The uterus is soft and enlarged; the blue spots represent subserous endometriosis.

questions.text: A patient with menorrhagia and backache is diagnosed with adenomyosis. Which of the following is not associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Adenomyosis is not associated with sub involution of the uterus.

Uterine subinvolution is impaired or retarded involution of the uterus. It is associated with uterine fibroid, cesarean section and conditions causing overdistension of the uterus like twin pregnancies or polyhydramnios.

Adenomyosis often coexists with the following conditions:

  • Uterine fibromyomas
  • Pelvic endometriosis (15%)
  • Endometrial carcinoma

questions.text: A 43-year-old multiparous woman presented with menorrhagia and secondary dysmenorrhea. On examination, Halban's sign was positive. The transvaginal USG findings are given below. Which of the following is the definitive treatment for her condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the transvaginal ultrasound(TVS) showing the Venetian blind appearance is suggestive of adenomyosis. The definitive treatment for adenomyosis is hysterectomy.

Adenomyosis (endometriosis interna) is the ingrowth of stromal and glandular components of the endometrium directly into the myometrium. Diagnosis is mainly based on clinical assessment. Painful, symmetrical enlargement of the uterus is suggestive of adenomyosis. On bimanual examination, the uterus is softened and tender. This is known as Halban's sign. 

TVS findings include salt and pepper appearance of the myometrium and the presence of subendometrial striations producing the Venetian blind appearance. MRI can also be done for diagnosis. However, the only definitive mode of diagnosis is histopathological examination.

Since most women affected by the condition are past the childbearing age, total hysterectomy is the treatment of choice. Localized excision/Levonorgestrel containing IUCD can be tried in younger women.
